title: JavaTreeMap - Q0001
text: Which package contains the TreeMap class?
explanation: The TreeMap class is part of the java.util package.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0002
text: Which interface does TreeMap implement?
explanation: TreeMap implements the NavigableMap interface.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0003
text: Which data structure does TreeMap use internally?
explanation: TreeMap uses a Red-Black Tree internally to store key-value pairs in sorted order.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0004
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and ordering?

options.text: TreeMap maintains keys in sorted order

explanation: TreeMap maintains keys in sorted order according to their natural ordering or a comparator.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0005
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and null keys?

options.text: TreeMap does not allow null keys

explanation: TreeMap does not allow null keys because it uses comparisons for ordering.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0006
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and null values?

options.text: TreeMap allows only one null value
TreeMap does not allow null values
TreeMap throws exception for null values

explanation: TreeMap allows multiple null values but not null keys.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0007
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and duplicates?

options.text: TreeMap does not allow duplicate keys

explanation: TreeMap does not allow duplicate keys, but values can be duplicated.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0008
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and synchronization?
explanation: TreeMap is not synchronized and is not thread-safe by default.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0009
text: Which of the following methods can be used to synchronize a TreeMap?
explanation: The Collections.synchronizedSortedMap() method returns a synchronized version of the map.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0010
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and performance?

options.text: TreeMap provides O(log n) time for get, put, and remove
TreeMap provides O(1) time for get, put, and remove
TreeMap provides O(n) time for get, put, and remove
TreeMap provides O(n^2) time for get, put, and remove

explanation: TreeMap provides O(log n) time complexity for get, put, and remove operations.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0011
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and comparator?

options.text: TreeMap can use a custom comparator for sorting keys

explanation: TreeMap can use a custom comparator for sorting keys.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0012
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and natural ordering?

options.text: Natural ordering is based on Comparable interface
Natural ordering is based on hashCode()
Natural ordering is based on equals()

explanation: Natural ordering in TreeMap is based on the Comparable interface implementation.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0013
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and firstKey()?
explanation: The firstKey() method returns the lowest key in the map.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0014
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and lastKey()?
explanation: The lastKey() method returns the highest key in the map.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0015
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and headMap()?

options.text: headMap() returns keys less than a given key
headMap() returns keys greater than a given key

explanation: The headMap() method returns keys less than the specified key.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0016
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and tailMap()?

options.text: tailMap() returns keys greater than or equal to a given key
tailMap() returns keys less than a given key

explanation: The tailMap() method returns keys greater than or equal to the specified key.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0017
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and subMap()?

options.text: subMap() returns keys between two specified keys

explanation: The subMap() method returns keys between two specified keys.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0018
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and descendingMap()?

options.text: descendingMap() returns a reverse order view of the map
descendingMap() returns a sorted order view

explanation: The descendingMap() method returns a reverse order view of the map.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0019
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and ceilingKey()?

options.text: ceilingKey() returns the least key greater than or equal to the given key
ceilingKey() returns the greatest key less than or equal to the given key

explanation: The ceilingKey() method returns the least key greater than or equal to the given key.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0020
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and floorKey()?

options.text: floorKey() returns the greatest key less than or equal to the given key
floorKey() returns the least key greater than or equal to the given key

explanation: The floorKey() method returns the greatest key less than or equal to the given key.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0021
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and higherKey()?

options.text: higherKey() returns the least key strictly greater than the given key
higherKey() returns the greatest key less than the given key

explanation: The higherKey() method returns the least key strictly greater than the given key.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0022
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and lowerKey()?

options.text: lowerKey() returns the greatest key strictly less than the given key
lowerKey() returns the least key greater than the given key

explanation: The lowerKey() method returns the greatest key strictly less than the given key.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0023
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and pollFirstEntry()?

options.text: pollFirstEntry() retrieves and removes the lowest entry
pollFirstEntry() retrieves and removes the highest entry
pollFirstEntry() retrieves but does not remove the lowest entry

explanation: The pollFirstEntry() method retrieves and removes the lowest entry in the map.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0024
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and pollLastEntry()?

options.text: pollLastEntry() retrieves and removes the highest entry
pollLastEntry() retrieves and removes the lowest entry
pollLastEntry() retrieves but does not remove the highest entry

explanation: The pollLastEntry() method retrieves and removes the highest entry in the map.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0025
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and comparator()?

options.text: comparator() returns the comparator used for ordering

explanation: The comparator() method returns the comparator used for ordering, or null if natural ordering is used.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0026
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and entrySet()?

options.text: entrySet() returns a set view of key-value pairs

explanation: The entrySet() method returns a set view of key-value pairs in the map.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0027
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and keySet()?

options.text: keySet() returns a set view of keys
keySet() returns a collection of values
keySet() returns a map of entries

explanation: The keySet() method returns a set view of the keys contained in the map.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0028
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and values()?

options.text: values() returns a collection view of all values
values() returns a set of keys
values() returns a map of entries

explanation: The values() method returns a collection view of all values in the map.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0029
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and put()?

options.text: put() adds or replaces a key-value pair

explanation: The put() method adds a new key-value pair or replaces the value if the key already exists.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0030
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and get()?

options.text: get() returns the value associated with a key

explanation: The get() method returns the value associated with the specified key.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0031
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and remove()?

options.text: remove() deletes a key or key-value pair

explanation: The remove() method deletes a key or key-value pair from the map.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0032
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and replace()?

options.text: replace() updates the value for a given key

explanation: The replace() method updates the value for a given key if it exists.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0033
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and containsKey()?

options.text: containsKey() checks if a key exists
containsKey() checks if a value exists

explanation: The containsKey() method checks if a key exists in the map.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0034
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and containsValue()?

options.text: containsValue() checks if a value exists
containsValue() checks if a key exists

explanation: The containsValue() method checks if a value exists in the map.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0035
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and clear()?
explanation: The clear() method removes all key-value pairs from the map.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0036
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and size()?

options.text: size() returns the number of key-value pairs

explanation: The size() method returns the number of key-value pairs in the map.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0037
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and isEmpty()?

options.text: isEmpty() checks if the map has no entries

explanation: The isEmpty() method checks if the map contains no key-value pairs.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0038
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and clone()?

options.text: clone() creates a shallow copy of the map
clone() creates a deep copy of the map

explanation: The clone() method creates a shallow copy of the TreeMap.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0039
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and serialization?

options.text: TreeMap cannot be written to a stream

explanation: TreeMap implements Serializable, allowing it to be serialized.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0040
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and thread safety?
explanation: TreeMap is not thread-safe; external synchronization is required.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0041
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and fail-fast behavior?
explanation: TreeMap iterators are fail-fast and throw ConcurrentModificationException if modified during iteration.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0042
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and equals()?

options.text: equals() compares two maps for key-value equality

explanation: The equals() method compares two maps for key-value equality.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0043
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and hashCode()?
explanation: The hashCode() of a TreeMap depends on the hash codes of its entries.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0044
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and replaceAll()?

options.text: replaceAll() replaces each value using a function

explanation: The replaceAll() method replaces each value using the provided function.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0045
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and forEach()?

options.text: forEach() performs an action for each key-value pair

explanation: The forEach() method performs the specified action for each key-value pair in the map.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0046
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and computeIfAbsent()?

options.text: computeIfAbsent() computes a value if the key is not present

explanation: The computeIfAbsent() method computes and inserts a value if the key is not already present.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0047
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and computeIfPresent()?

options.text: computeIfPresent() updates a value if the key is present

explanation: The computeIfPresent() method updates a value using a remapping function if the key is present.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0048
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and merge()?

options.text: merge() combines values for duplicate keys using a function

explanation: The merge() method combines values for duplicate keys using a specified function.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0049
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and immutability?
explanation: TreeMap is mutable; elements can be added or removed.

title: JavaTreeMap - Q0050
text: Which of the following best describes TreeMap?

options.text: A map implementation that stores key-value pairs in sorted order using a Red-Black tree

explanation: TreeMap is a map implementation that stores key-value pairs in sorted order using a Red-Black tree.
